questions.question: You're on GitHub, a code sharing platform, looking through some recommended codebases when one of them catches your eye. It does exactly what you need it to do. As such, you want to use it in your own project. What's the first thing you should do?

options.answer: Read the license for the code.
options.explanation: It's always a good idea to check what restrictions the codewriter has set for modifying and distributing their code. There are a variety of different licenses that require different things, from the GNU Public License v3 (GPLv3) to the MIT License.

options.answer: Copy and paste the code, and don't give any attribution.
options.explanation: This is very unethical and possibly criminal as you are intentionally misappropriating someone else's intellectual property and output.

options.answer: Copy and paste the code, and include a link reference in a comment.
options.explanation: While you may have used the code in good faith, the owner of the codebase may have added a license on the code that either requires certain stipulations or outright forbids reuse of their code. If this exists, you would be misappropriating their intellectual property.

options.answer: Copy and paste the code, and write the author of the code in a comment.
options.explanation: While you may have used the code in good faith, the owner of the codebase may have added a license on the code that either requires certain stipulations or outright forbids reuse of their code. If this exists, you would be misappropriating their intellectual property.

questions.question: You're on Google researching a niche subject. Somehow, someway, you stumble upon a confidential document that was indexed by the search engine (this actually happens!). What do you do?

options.answer: Determine the source/owner of the material, and blackmail them.
options.explanation: This is both highly unethical as you're using computers to harm people. Blackmail is also very illegal, and would likely get you arrested.

options.answer: Contact the original owner of the material, letting them know that said document is available publicly.
options.explanation: Notifying the original owner is very ethical and a good idea as they can take appropriate action to take the document down and alert any other affected parties.

options.answer: Sell the information to someone else.
options.explanation: This is unethical because you're using computers to harm people. The buying party may also participate in illegal/unethical actions because of your help.

options.answer: Read over the file yourself, download a copy, and continue on with the rest of your day.
options.explanation: While this might be what most people do, it is still unethical as you're snooping through a entity's private files.

questions.question: You're in a public Discord server when you notice someone cyberbullying a kid. They're calling them slurs and threatening them. What do you do?

options.answer: Stand up for the person being bullied and report them.
options.explanation: It's ethical to be an upstander.

options.answer: Join in the bullying as well, and call them names.
options.explanation: It's unethical to use computers and the internet to bully people.
It's unethical to be a bystander when you have the ability to easily stand up for someone.

questions.question: Your friend runs a hacking service that can break into a person's social media accounts. He offers you a 50% discount because you're friends with him. Do you:

options.answer: Use the discount and ask him to hack someone.
options.explanation: Hacking is extremely unethical and illegal, and can get you in a lot of trouble.
Hacking is extremely unethical and illegal, and can get you in a lot of trouble. By refusing, you are avoiding a lot of trouble.
